** FREE ADVANCED SCREENING - NEVER BACK DOWN **



TUESDAY, MARCH 11TH @ 7PM
Lowes Boston Common Theater


Never Back Down, is a story about a rebellious teen (Sean Faris), who at his new high school is lured into an underground fight club, where he finds a mentor in a mixed martial arts veteran (Djimon Hounsou). Full synopsis included below, more information available at NEVER BACK DOWN

Please print out the pass located in the group's file for admission, each pass admits two - feel free to print as many as you need. Just as an FYI: seating is not guaranteed and is available on a first come first served basis, so arrive early!

Email advanced.screening@gmail.com with "NEVER BACK DOWN" as the subject line if you have any further questions.


Synopsis :
Set against the action-packed world of Mixed Martial Arts, NEVER BACK DOWN is the story of Jake Tyler, a tough kid who leads with his fists, and, often, with his heart. Jake Tyler, played by Sean Faris, is the new kid in town with a troubled past. He has recently moved to Orlando, Florida with his family who has relocated to support his younger brothers shot at a professional tennis career. Jake was a star athlete on the football team at home, but in this new city he is an outsider with a reputation for being a quick tempered brawler. Making an attempt to fit in, at the invitation of a flirtatious classmate, Baja (Amber Heard), Jake goes to a party where he is unwittingly pulled into a fight with a bully named Ryan McDonald (Cam Gigandet). While he is defeated and humiliated in the fight, a classmate introduces himself to Jake and tells him about the sport known as Mixed Marshall Arts (MMA). He sees a star in Jake and asks that he meet with his mentor, Jean Roqua, played by Djimon Hounsou (Blood Diamond, In America). It is immediately apparent to Jake that MMA is not street fighting, but rather an art form he wants to master. Roqua will take Jake under his wing, but it is up to Jake to find the patience, discipline, willingness and reason within him to succeed. For Jake, there is much more at stake than mere victory. His decision will not just settle a score; it will define who he is.

Rated: PG 13
Runtime: 110 minutes

Opens: March 14th
